bibl.title: Military Orders for John S. Neate and James Carroll, February 6, 1901 [selected page]

div1.p: Special Orders #31, Headquarters Department of Cuba, directs Neate and Carroll to Washington, D. C. for duty in the Army Medical Museum. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for John S. Neate and James Carroll, February 6, 1901 [selected page]
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, February 6, 1901.

1. In compliance with paragraph 5, Special Orders No.
18, current series, Headquarters of the Army, Hospital
Steward John S. Neate, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, is
hereby relieved from duty at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and
will proceed to Washington, District of Columbia, reporting
upon arrival to Major John Van R. Hoff, Surgeon U. S.
Army, medical supply officer, for duty in the pathological
laboratory at the Army Medical Museum.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department will
commute his rations, in advance, at the authorized rate for
one (1) day while delayed in New York City and traveling
by rail.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the
necessary transportation for a detachment of recruits for
the 8th Cavalry, now at Matanzas, Cuba, en route to join
regiment, from that point to Camp Mackenzie, Puerto
Principe, Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. The journey performed by 2d Lieutenant Evan H.
Humphrey, 7th Cavalry, Acting Assistant Quartermaster,
from this city to Matanzas, Cuba, in connection with the
grounding of the Army Transport McPherson, is approved
and made of record as having been necessary for the public
service.

4. Lieutenant Evan H. Humphrey, 7th Cavalry, Acting
Assistant Quartermaster, now at Matanzas, Cuba, having
completed the duty assigned him by the Chief Quarter-
master of the Department, will return to his proper station,
Havana, Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Acting Assist-
ant Surgeon James Carroll, U. S. Army, now on duty with
the medical board of officers pursuing scientific investiga-
tion as to infectious diseases in Cuba, is hereby relieved
with said board and will proceed to Washington, D. C., re-
porting to the Surgeon General of the Army for duty in the
medical museum at that point.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

J. B. HICKEY,
Acting Adjutant General.
